Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "More telemetry for downloads service." (#9361) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Related to https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9352.

We have a weird situation when downloads.v1.json, Gallery DB and Search service all align on a downloads count for a certain package, yet the number displayed in the package list is different.

It should come from DB: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/c1ccf24a931fb3e048e23c484f663580e906f30d/src/NuGetGallery/Helpers/ViewModelExtensions/PackageViewModelFactory.cs#L58
But some EF interception magic happens and it is actually ends up being populated from data retrieved by [CloudDownloadCountService](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/main/src/NuGetGallery/Services/CloudDownloadCountService.cs) and it is unclear if it actually refreshes the statistics data fully. To investigate the issue from that angle, more telemetry is added to that service.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "AAD account checks on packages for safety reports" (#9360) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: We'll allow safety report categories only on MSA-only account-owned packages as a first step.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Search-by-TFM feature flight UI bug fix" (#9357) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Part of https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4579

**Problem:**
When the Search-by-TFM feature flight was disabled for a user, as it will be for most users to begin with, the 'sort by' dropdown didn't automatically submit the form when a user changed its value.

**Fix:**
The new `frameworks` and `tfms` input fields in the html form were hidden behind the feature flight but still being referenced by some javascript code, which caused errors and prevented all the javascript code below it in the file from running. This code included the sort by event handler.

The `frameworks` and `tfms` were hidden form fields, so I've just moved them outside the feature flight to avoid errors. There is no visible change.

I've also moved the framework checkbox initialization code to the bottom of the javascript file so that it can't cause similar issues with other code.

I've also added a title attribute to one of the html links to fix an a11y issue I noticed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "How to include a readme reference is not clear" (#9359) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

Other

### Describe the bug

On the upload page, there is warning message about missing readme. the refence link "how to include a readme" is not insufficient. it doesn't point to how to include a readme.  
it links to this page now. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/create-packages/package-authoring-best-practices#readme

### Repro Steps

1. go to nuget.org upload page
2.  upload a package without embedded readme
3.  see warning message, click link.

### Expected Behavior

Links to actually documentation how to include a readme

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Nuget.exe CLI not getting correct versions when running in -ExcludeVersion mode" (#12384) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

Nuget 6.4.0.123

### Worked before?

unknown

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

##Context: 

When using Install -ExcludeVersion mode and changing the desired version in packages.config, Nuget.exe does not actually replace the package with the desired version.  Note that this issue only occurs when the packages are already cached -- if the cache is freshly cleared using `nuget locals all -clear`, this does not occur.  `-nocache` does not help.

In powershell, in a fresh folder, execute the following:

'''ps

if(Test-path packages) {rm packages -r}

'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?>
<packages>
  <package id="SqlServer" version="21.0.17099" />
</packages>' > packages.config

'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <clear />
    <add key="PSGallery" value="https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/" />
  </packageSources>
  <config>
    <add key="repositoryPath" value=".\packages" />
  </config>
</configuration>' > nuget.config

Write-Output "* INSTALLING OLD VERSION *"

nuget install packages.config -excludeversion -verbosity detailed

Write-Output "* DOWNLOADED VERSION: $((Import-PowershellDataFile "./packages/SqlServer/SqlServer.psd1").ModuleVersion) *"

'<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?>
 <packages>
   <package id="SqlServer" version="21.1.18245" />
</packages>' > packages.config

Write-Output "* INSTALLING NEW VERSION *"

nuget install packages.config -excludeversion -verbosity detailed

Write-Output "* DOWNLOADED VERSION: $((Import-PowershellDataFile "./packages/SqlServer/SqlServer.psd1").ModuleVersion) *"
'''

See in the logs below, the DOWNLOADED VERSION remains unchanged after the second `nuget install` command.

### Verbose Logs

```shell
* INSTALLING OLD VERSION *
NuGet Version: 6.4.0.123
Feeds used:
  C:\Users\zaratem\.nuget\packages\
  https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/

Restoring NuGet package SqlServer.21.0.17099.
Adding package 'SqlServer.21.0.17099' to folder 'C:\temp\NugetBugDemo\packages'
Added package 'SqlServer.21.0.17099' to folder 'C:\temp\NugetBugDemo\packages'
Added package 'SqlServer.21.0.17099' to folder 'C:\temp\NugetBugDemo\packages' from source 'C:\Users\zaratem\.nuget\packages\'
* DOWNLOADED VERSION: 21.0.17099 *
* INSTALLING NEW VERSION *
NuGet Version: 6.4.0.123
Feeds used:
  C:\Users\zaratem\.nuget\packages\
  https://www.powershellgallery.com/api/v2/

Restoring NuGet package SqlServer.21.1.18245.
Adding package 'SqlServer.21.1.18245' to folder 'C:\temp\NugetBugDemo\packages'
Added package 'SqlServer.21.1.18245' to folder 'C:\temp\NugetBugDemo\packages'
Added package 'SqlServer.21.1.18245' to folder 'C:\temp\NugetBugDemo\packages' from source 'C:\Users\zaratem\.nuget\packages\'
* DOWNLOADED VERSION: 21.0.17099 *
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Out of Memory on Simple project with dotnet restore" (#12383) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I am running dotnet restore as part of a Jenkins build pipeline. The restore often fails with variations on OutOfMemory. I initially increased the 8Gb RAM on the machine to 16Gb, but this had no effect.

The solution is relatively straightforward, containing c. 12 projects. None of these project are unusual, excepting perhaps that they are all .NET Framework 4.8 based. They all build on Visual Studio 2022 without problems.

To recreate the situation, I ran two command-line processes on the build machine, both of which failed. The command lines were:

> D:\Build_Pipeline>dotnet restore -v diag Client\DeptXWindowsService.sln 1> dotnet-restore.txt 2>&1

> D:\Build_Pipeline>dotnet restore --disable-parallel -v diag Client\DeptXWindowsService.sln 1> dotnet-restore-disable-parallel.txt 2>&1

[dotnet-restore.txt](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/10498109/dotnet-restore.txt)
[dotnet-restore-disable-parallel.txt](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/10498110/dotnet-restore-disable-parallel.txt)

This created the two outputs below. You can see that both processes have exited with a failure after apparently running out of memory. Memory usage is only around 5% of the 16Gb before running these processes. This also takes quite some time. As this is not the only solution in our build pipeline, this slows our build pipeline significantly. 

What can I do to stop this happening?

Versions Information:
D:\Build_Pipeline>msbuild /version
MSBuild version 17.4.1+9a89d02ff for .NET Framework
17.4.1.60106
D:\Build_Pipeline>dotnet --version
7.0.102

Allow the inclusion of additional metadata properties in package authoring and allow them to be used in search queries.

The motivation for this is to create associations of NuGet packages which bind and/or redistribute platform native libraries on other platforms and package management systems.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Support declaring PackageSourceMappings via MSBuild items" (#12382) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

Packages provided directly via the SDK (via the pre-existing LibraryPacks feature or other mechanisms) previously have had some sharp edges with Package Source Mapping and Central Package Version Management. https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/27840 is one example of this, but there have been some enhancements to those mechanisms to automatically filter out certain kinds of packages or package sources (e.g. https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11951). This is a great approach, but a future-facing approach might be to allow the SDK to programmatically update Package Source and Mappings for sources and packages that it contributes via adding certain kinds of MSBuild metadata or items - that pushes the work onto the SDK team and relieves the NuGet logic from having to update these distinctions if the desired logic should change at some future time.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue ".NET Framework (non-SDK) projects don't load IsImplicityDefined metadata on PackageReferences" (#12377) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

all?

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

Have a non-SDK style project, and a PackageReference item with `IsDefinedImplicitly="true"`. For example:

```xml
<PackageReference Include="NuGet.Versioning" Version="6.4.0" IsDefinedImplicitly="true" />
```

Then, open the Package Manager UI, go to the installed tab, and try to change the package version.  If you do this with an SDK style project, you'll see the version selection is disabled, with the top entry saying "Disabled by project".  When you try this with a non-SDK style project, it lets you change the version, and when the PackageReference comes from a read-only file (for example, a targets file in the Visual Studio install directory), trying to install the package fails.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Static graph-based restore crashes on systems with alternate console encodings" (#12373) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

Visual Studio 17.5 and above

### Worked before?

Yes, Visual Studio 17.4

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

In Windows Region settings, enable "Use Unicode UTF-8 for worldwide language support"

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17556515/213275269-9fd1c932-a002-4da7-9dd1-786230fb913e.png)

This seems to make Console.StandardInput have a 3-byte preamble, causing the logic that read the static graph restore arguments to not work correctly.

Reported by @vlada-shubina

Caused by https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/4772

### Workaround
Disable the Windows Region setting and reboot.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Incorrectly appending dot to a package name should produce better error message" (#12380) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

.NET SDK 8.0.100-alpha.1.22567.28

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

When you try to `dotnet add package` using the wrong name of a package, you get a relatively reasonable error message:

```
> dotnet add package Newtonsoft.Json/
  Determining projects to restore...
  Writing C:\Users\Svick\AppData\Local\Temp\tmp4frdea.tmp
info : X.509 certificate chain validation will use the default trust store selected by .NET.
info : X.509 certificate chain validation will use the default trust store selected by .NET.
info : Adding PackageReference for package 'Newtonsoft.Json/' into project 'C:\code\tmp\hwapp\hwapp.csproj'.
info :   GET https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/registrations2-semver2/newtonsoft.json//index.json
info :   GET https://api.nuget.org/v3/registration5-gz-semver2/newtonsoft.json//index.json
info :   NotFound https://api.nuget.org/v3/registration5-gz-semver2/newtonsoft.json//index.json 928ms
info :   NotFound https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/registrations2-semver2/newtonsoft.json//index.json 1053ms
info :   GET https://api.nuget.org/v3/registration5-gz-semver2/newtonsoft.json//index.json
info :   GET https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/registrations2-semver2/newtonsoft.json//index.json
info :   NotFound https://api.nuget.org/v3/registration5-gz-semver2/newtonsoft.json//index.json 311ms
info :   NotFound https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/registrations2-semver2/newtonsoft.json//index.json 745ms
error: There are no versions available for the package 'Newtonsoft.Json/'.


Usage: NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat.dll package add [options]

Options:
  -h|--help               Show help information
  --force-english-output  Forces the application to run using an invariant, English-based culture.
  --package               Id of the package to be added.
  --version               Version of the package to be added.
  -d|--dg-file            Path to the dependency graph file to be used to restore preview and compatibility check.
  -p|--project            Path to the project file.
  -f|--framework          Frameworks for which the package reference should be added.
  -n|--no-restore         Do not perform restore preview and compatibility check. The added package reference will be unconditional.
  -s|--source             Specifies NuGet package sources to use during the restore.
  --package-directory     Directory to restore packages in.
  --interactive           Allow the command to block and require manual action for operations like authentication.
  --prerelease            Allows prerelease packages to be installed.
```

(This could be improved, see https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12379, but that's not what this issue is about.)

But when the wrong name is because of adding `.` to the package name (e.g. because of copy-pasting from the end of a sentence), the error is:

```
> dotnet add package Newtonsoft.Json.
  Determining projects to restore...
  Writing C:\Users\Svick\AppData\Local\Temp\tmpnapwll.tmp
info : X.509 certificate chain validation will use the default trust store selected by .NET.
info : X.509 certificate chain validation will use the default trust store selected by .NET.
info : Adding PackageReference for package 'Newtonsoft.Json.' into project 'C:\code\tmp\hwapp\hwapp.csproj'.
info :   CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3/registration5-gz-semver2/newtonsoft.json./index.json
info :   GET https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/registrations2-semver2/newtonsoft.json./index.json
info :   NotFound https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/registrations2-semver2/newtonsoft.json./index.json 181ms
info : Restoring packages for C:\code\tmp\hwapp\hwapp.csproj...
info :   GET https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/flat2/newtonsoft.json./index.json
info :   CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/newtonsoft.json./index.json

info :   NotFound https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/newtonsoft.json./13.0.2/newtonsoft.json..13.0.2.nupkg 719ms
info :   GET https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/newtonsoft.json./index.json
info :   NotFound https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/flat2/newtonsoft.json./index.json 993ms
info :   GET https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/flat2/newtonsoft.json./index.json
info :   NotFound https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/flat2/newtonsoft.json./index.json 319ms
info :   GET https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/flat2/newtonsoft.json./index.json
info :   NotFound https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/flat2/newtonsoft.json./index.json 261ms
info :   OK https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/newtonsoft.json./index.json 592ms
info :   CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/newtonsoft.json./index.json
info :   GET https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/dnceng/9ee6d478-d288-47f7-aacc-f6e6d082ae6d/_packaging/d1622942-d16f-48e5-bc83-96f4539e7601/nuget/v3/flat2/newtonsoft.json./index.json
info :   CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/newtonsoft.json./index.json
info : Package 'Newtonsoft.Json.' is compatible with all the specified frameworks in project 'C:\code\tmp\hwapp\hwapp.csproj'.
error: Value cannot be null. (Parameter 'version')


Usage: NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat.dll package add [options]

Options:
  -h|--help               Show help information
  --force-english-output  Forces the application to run using an invariant, English-based culture.
  --package               Id of the package to be added.
  --version               Version of the package to be added.
  -d|--dg-file            Path to the dependency graph file to be used to restore preview and compatibility check.
  -p|--project            Path to the project file.
  -f|--framework          Frameworks for which the package reference should be added.
  -n|--no-restore         Do not perform restore preview and compatibility check. The added package reference will be unconditional.
  -s|--source             Specifies NuGet package sources to use during the restore.
  --package-directory     Directory to restore packages in.
  --interactive           Allow the command to block and require manual action for operations like authentication.
  --prerelease            Allows prerelease packages to be installed.
```

Nothing in the output indicates what the error actually is. That should be changed.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

```
error: There are no versions available for the package 'Newtonsoft.Json/'.


Usage: NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat.dll package add [options]

Options:
  -h|--help               Show help information
  --force-english-output  Forces the application to run using an invariant, English-based culture.
  --package               Id of the package to be added.
  --version               Version of the package to be added.
  -d|--dg-file            Path to the dependency graph file to be used to restore preview and compatibility check.
  -p|--project            Path to the project file.
  -f|--framework          Frameworks for which the package reference should be added.
  -n|--no-restore         Do not perform restore preview and compatibility check. The added package reference will be unconditional.
  -s|--source             Specifies NuGet package sources to use during the restore.
  --package-directory     Directory to restore packages in.
  --interactive           Allow the command to block and require manual action for operations like authentication.

Usage: NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat.dll package add [options]

Options:
  -h|--help               Show help information
  --force-english-output  Forces the application to run using an invariant, English-based culture.
  --package               Id of the package to be added.
  --version               Version of the package to be added.
  -d|--dg-file            Path to the dependency graph file to be used to restore preview and compatibility check.
  -p|--project            Path to the project file.
  -f|--framework          Frameworks for which the package reference should be added.
  -n|--no-restore         Do not perform restore preview and compatibility check. The added package reference will be unconditional.
  -s|--source             Specifies NuGet package sources to use during the restore.
  --package-directory     Directory to restore packages in.
  --interactive           Allow the command to block and require manual action for operations like authentication.
  --prerelease            Allows prerelease packages to be installed.
```

My issues with this are:

1. It's almost 30 lines of output, most of them fairly long, but only one of them is the actual error message I want to see. Specifically:

    1. The `info` messages are not going to be useful most of the time. `dotnet build` defaults the minimal verbosity, and allows the user to see more information when useful. `dotnet add package` should do the same.
    2. The Usage section can be useful when the user makes a mistake in the usage of the command. But when the mistake is in the name of the package, it just adds noise.
2. The error message is unclear. It says that "there are no versions available for the package", when the actual error is that the package does not exist. (Bonus points if the message corrected the spelling of the package name.)
3. The `info:` formatting doesn't follow the color-coded unprefixed formatting of `dotnet build`.

### Desired Behavior

Ideally, the output should look something like this:

```
> dotnet add package Newtonsoft.Json/
The package 'Newtonsoft.Json/' does not exist. Did you mean 'Newtonsoft.Json'?
```

### Additional Context

_No response_

This covers the package source mapping commands for the dotnet add package command (or maybe even, dotnet update package).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Plan for NuGet in 2022" (#11571) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Today we are excited to share with you the plan for NuGet and NuGet.org. This issue contains summary of the plan for the year and acts as a place for you to leave feedback.

This plan is a collection of input from many stakeholders and outlines where we intend to invest our time in NuGet and NuGet.org.

> **IMPORTANT**
> This plan is not a commitment; it will evolve as we continue to learn throughout the release. Some things that are not currently planned for NuGet may get pulled in. Some things currently planned may even be pushed out.

# General information

NuGet has a major release following [NuGet 6.0](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/release-notes/nuget-6.0) and is currently scheduled for release in November 2022 at the same time as .NET 7.

NuGet will align with the [.NET support policy](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/platform/support/policy/dotnet-core) and will therefore **not** be a long-term support (LTS) release.

NuGet.org does not currently follow any specific schedule and releases features & bug fixes regularly throughout the year.

### Breaking changes

NuGet may contain a small number of breaking changes as we continue to evolve NuGet with the .NET platform. Our goal is to minimize breaking changes as much as possible to keep you productive when upgrading.

## Themes

The large investments in NuGet are the following themes:

### Highly Requested Features

As always, a major input into our planning process comes from [votes (üëç) for features on GitHub](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/blob/dev/CONTRIBUTING.md#before-submitting-an-issue).

These features are areas we are actively engaged in with regards to designing, implementing, and polishing the respective experiences for.

#### NuGet Tooling

- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6764
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11752
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10730
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7752
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/4103
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8087
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5887
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/1851
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11262

#### NuGet Gallery

- https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/3098
- https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4843
- https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8964

### .NET Platforms and Ecosystem

Much of the work planned for NuGet involves improving the package management experience for .NET across different platforms and ecosystem. This involves work in NuGet to ensure a great experience across .NET technologies.

- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5926
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9667
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10800
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10430
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10872

### Migrating to .NET

NuGet has always [supported many scenarios for package management](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/migrate-packages-config-to-package-reference). In our continued efforts to help you migrate to the latest version of .NET, we will be working on improvements to the [Upgrade Assistant](https://github.com/dotnet/upgrade-assistant) and core package management experiences to help you migrate your project to use the latest version of NuGet.

## Performance

With each [new release of NuGet & Visual Studio comes a plethora of performance improvements](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/visualstudio/performance-improvements-in-nuget/) when restoring NuGet packages, managing project dependencies, and browsing for the next great package to include in your solution. We will continue to invest time to improve your experiences every .NET & Visual Studio release.

# Feedback

Your feedback is important to us. The best way to indicate the importance of an issue is to vote (üëç) for that [issue on GitHub](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues) and [Visual Studio Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/). We use this data to help us with our regular planning so we can work on the things that matter most to you.

Please **comment on this issue** if you believe we are missing something that is critical for NuGet, or are focusing on the wrong areas. Give us a little bit of context as to why you believe so and feel free to upvote each other's comments to help us make changes to our future plans.

Huge thanks to @ajcvickers and the Entity Framework Core team for a wonderful format and forum to discuss product plans in OSS. üéâ
